UI_visible_response: Mass surveillance in the People's Republic of China (PRC) involves an extensive network of monitoring systems utilized by the central government to oversee its citizens1. This surveillance apparatus has been developed over twenty-five years, extending from urban areas like Beijing's alleyways to rural villages, creating what is often described as a mass surveillance state3.State surveillance is not only pervasive but also a daily reality for Chinese citizens. As a result, people have begun developing mental strategies to cope with the omnipresence of digital surveillance4. The extent of this surveillance includes the highest density of CCTV cameras in the world, with police agencies frequently employing facial recognition technology5.Companies such as Dahua, the second-largest surveillance camera manufacturer globally, contribute significantly to this infrastructure, exporting their technologies worldwide and exemplifying the reach of Chinese surveillance capabilities6. While these systems are intended to maintain social order and security, they have also raised concerns about privacy and human rights2.
traffic_visible_response: Mass surveillance in the People's Republic of China (PRC) involves an extensive network of monitoring systems utilized by the central government to oversee its citizens [[1]]. This surveillance apparatus has been developed over twenty-five years, extending from urban areas like Beijing's alleyways to rural villages, creating what is often described as a mass surveillance state [[3]]. State surveillance is not only pervasive but also a daily reality for Chinese citizens. As a result, people have begun developing mental strategies to cope with the omnipresence of digital surveillance [[4]]. The extent of this surveillance includes the highest density of CCTV cameras in the world, with police agencies frequently employing facial recognition technology [[5]].Companies such as Dahua, the second-largest surveillance camera manufacturer globally, contribute significantly to this infrastructure, exporting their technologies worldwide and exemplifying the reach of Chinese surveillance capabilities [[6]]. While these systems are intended to maintain social order and security, they have also raised concerns about privacy and human rights [[2]].
